o: The science of collecting, analyzing, and interpreting data

q: Statistics is divided into descriptive and ______ branches.
What is a population in statistics?
A sample is a ______ of the population.
Match the term with its definition:

o: The sum of values divided by the count

q: The mean is calculated as sum(x) / ______.
The mean is sensitive to outliers.

o: The middle value when data is sorted
The difference between max and min

q: For an odd number of values, the median is the ______ value.
The median is resistant to outliers.
A distribution can have more than one mode.
Match the measure with its property:
The range uses only two data points.

o: The average of squared deviations from the mean

q: Population variance divides by N, sample variance divides by ______.
Standard deviation has the same units as the ______ data.
A larger standard deviation means more spread.
Match the symbol with its meaning:

o: Q3 - Q1, the middle 50% of data
A value that divides data into four equal parts
A value below which a percentage of data falls

q: Match the percentile with the quartile:

o: A graph showing the five-number summary

q: A box plot shows min, Q1, median, Q3, and ______.
Outliers are typically shown as separate points on a box plot.

o: A graph showing frequency distribution of continuous data

q: In a histogram, bars are adjacent (no gaps) for continuous data.
Match the chart type with its best use:
The normal distribution is defined by mean mu and standard deviation ______.
About 68% of data falls within one standard deviation of the mean for a normal distribution.

o: The number of standard deviations from the mean

q: A z-score of 0 means the value equals the mean.
Match the z-score with its interpretation:
What is the standard normal distribution?
o: A normal distribution with mean 0 and std dev 1

q: The standard normal distribution has mean ______ and std dev 1.
Z-tables give probabilities for the standard normal distribution.

o: A measure of how likely an event is to occur

q: A probability of 0 means the event is impossible.
Match the probability with its meaning:
What is the addition rule of probability?
o: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

q: For mutually exclusive events, P(A or B) = P(A) + ______.
Mutually exclusive events cannot occur simultaneously.
What is the multiplication rule for independent events?
Independent events do not affect each other's probabilities.

o: P(A|B) = probability of A given B has occurred

q: Bayes' theorem allows us to update ______ based on new evidence.
Bayes' theorem is fundamental to Bayesian statistics.

o: A variable whose value is determined by a random event

q: Random variables can be discrete or ______.
A discrete random variable takes countable values.

o: A function giving probabilities for all possible values

q: The sum of all probabilities in a discrete distribution equals ______.
For continuous distributions, we use probability density functions.

o: The long-run average of the random variable

q: E[X] = sum of x * P(x) for discrete distributions.
Expected value is also called the ______.

o: Distribution of successes in n independent Bernoulli trials

q: A binomial distribution has parameters n and ______.
The binomial coefficient C(n,k) gives the number of ways to choose k from n.
For binomial distribution, E[X] = n * p.

o: Distribution of rare events in a fixed interval

q: For Poisson distribution, E[X] = Var(X) = lambda.
Match the distribution with its use case:

o: Distribution of time between events in a Poisson process
A generalization of the exponential distribution

q: The gamma distribution has parameters shape and ______.
When shape = 1, the gamma distribution is exponential.
Match the distribution with its relationship:
The beta distribution has parameters alpha and ______.
The beta distribution is the conjugate prior for binomial likelihood.

o: Sum of squared standard normal variables

q: Chi-squared distribution has ______ degrees of freedom as parameter.
The chi-squared distribution is used in goodness-of-fit tests.
Match the test with its distribution:

o: Distribution used for small samples when population std dev is unknown

q: The t-distribution has heavier ______ than normal.
As degrees of freedom increase, t-distribution approaches normal.

o: Ratio of two chi-squared variables divided by their degrees of freedom
A method to decide between competing claims using data

q: The alternative hypothesis is what we want to prove.

o: Probability of observing data as extreme as observed, given H0 is true

q: A small p-value provides evidence against the null hypothesis.
What is a Type I error?
o: Rejecting H0 when it is actually true
Failing to reject H0 when it is false

q: Type I error probability equals ______ (significance level).
Type I error is also called a false positive.
What is a Type II error?
o: Failing to reject H0 when it is actually false
Rejecting H0 when it is true

q: Type II error probability is denoted ______.
Type II error is also called a false negative.

o: Probability of correctly rejecting a false H0

q: Higher power means better ability to detect a true effect.
Match the factor with its effect on power:

o: A range of values likely to contain the population parameter

q: A 95% CI means we are 95% confident the interval contains the true ______.
Wider confidence intervals indicate more uncertainty.

o: A test comparing a sample mean to a hypothesized population mean

q: One-sample t-test assumes the population is approximately ______.

o: A test comparing means of two independent groups
Comparing a sample to a value

q: The pooled two-sample t-test assumes equal ______.
Welch's t-test does not assume equal variances.

o: A test for paired/matched observations (e.g., before-after)

q: Paired t-test analyzes the ______ between paired observations.
The paired t-test reduces variability by using pairs.
Match the scenario with test type:

o: Analysis of Variance - comparing means of 3+ groups

q: ANOVA tests if at least one group mean differs from others.
What is a chi-squared goodness-of-fit test?
o: A test comparing observed frequencies to expected frequencies

q: Chi-squared test requires expected frequencies of at least 5.

o: A measure of linear relationship between two variables

q: Match the correlation value with interpretation:

o: Modeling Y as a linear function of X: Y = a + bX + error

q: In Y = a + bX, b is the ______.
The regression line minimizes the sum of squared residuals.

o: Proportion of variance in Y explained by X

q: R-squared = r^2 for simple linear regression.
Multicollinearity occurs when predictors are highly correlated with each other.
Combinations count ______ where order doesn't matter.
What is the fundamental counting principle?
o: If one event can occur m ways and another n ways, both can occur m*n ways

q: For independent choices, multiply the number of ______.
The counting principle extends to any number of events.

o: The distribution of a statistic from all possible samples

q: The sampling distribution of x-bar has mean ______.
Standard error is the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
What is the Central Limit Theorem?
o: Sample means approach normal distribution as n increases

q: CLT applies when sample size is large (typically n >= ______).
CLT allows normal-based inference even for non-normal populations.

o: Dividing population into strata and sampling from each

q: Stratified sampling typically reduces variance compared to SRS.

o: Randomly selecting entire clusters and sampling all within

q: In cluster sampling, clusters should be ______ to the population.
Cluster sampling is often used for geographical convenience.
Match the sampling type with its advantage:
What is the law of large numbers?
o: Sample mean converges to population mean as n increases

q: LLN ensures ______ of the sample mean.
LLN is the theoretical justification for using sample means.

o: A single value estimate of a population parameter

q: The sample mean is a point estimate of the population ______.
Point estimates are subject to sampling error.

o: An estimator whose expected value equals the parameter

q: Sample variance with n-1 divisor is unbiased for population variance.

o: Finding parameter values that maximize the likelihood function

q: MLE finds the parameter that makes the data most ______.
MLE estimators are asymptotically normal and efficient.

o: A statistic that captures all information about a parameter

q: For normal distribution with known variance, x-bar is sufficient for ______.
Sufficient statistics allow data reduction without information loss.

o: Distribution of trials until first success

q: What is the negative binomial distribution?
o: Distribution of trials until r successes

q: Negative binomial can model overdispersed count data.

o: Sampling without replacement from a finite population

q: Hypergeometric differs from binomial in using sampling ______.
For large populations, hypergeometric approximates binomial.

o: A table showing frequency counts for two categorical variables

q: Contingency tables are analyzed with ______ tests.
The test of independence uses a contingency table.

o: A measure of the magnitude of a phenomenon

q: Cohen's d measures effect size in ______ units.
Effect size is independent of sample size.

o: A test that doesn't assume a specific distribution

q: Nonparametric tests use ______ or ranks instead of raw values.
Nonparametric tests are often more robust but less powerful.
Match the test with its nonparametric alternative:
What is the Mann-Whitney U test?
Mann-Whitney uses ______ instead of raw values.
Mann-Whitney tests if one distribution tends to have larger values.
What is the Wilcoxon signed-rank test?
The Wilcoxon test assumes symmetric distribution of differences.
Match the nonparametric test with its use:
Spearman correlation is robust to outliers.
Kruskal-Wallis tests if ______ distributions are the same.
Kruskal-Wallis uses ranks of all observations combined.
Match the ANOVA type with its nonparametric version:
Logistic regression models the log ______ of success.
Logistic regression uses maximum likelihood estimation.

o: Ratio of odds of an event in two groups

q: Odds ratio is commonly used in logistic regression interpretation.
The Kaplan-Meier curve estimates the survival function.
What is the Cox proportional hazards model?
o: A semi-parametric model for survival data relating hazard to covariates

q: Cox regression does not require specifying the baseline hazard.

o: A test comparing survival curves between groups

q: Log-rank test is nonparametric and uses ______.
Log-rank test gives more weight to later time points.

o: Updating prior beliefs with data to get posterior

q: In Bayesian inference, posterior is proportional to prior times ______.
Bayesian credible intervals have direct probability interpretation.

o: A prior that results in posterior from the same family

q: Conjugate priors make Bayesian computation easier.

o: Markov Chain Monte Carlo - sampling from complex distributions

q: MCMC generates samples from the ______ distribution.
Gibbs sampling is a type of MCMC.

o: Distribution representing beliefs before seeing data

q: An uninformative prior gives ______ weight to all values.

o: Assessing model performance by training/testing on different subsets

q: k-fold CV splits data into ______ parts.
Leave-one-out CV uses n-1 observations for training.

o: Model fits training data too closely but generalizes poorly

q: Overfitting is indicated by low training error and high ______ error.

o: Adding penalty to model complexity to prevent overfitting

q: L2 regularization (Ridge) shrinks coefficients toward zero but doesn't set them exactly to zero.

o: Akaike Information Criterion - balances fit and complexity

q: AIC = 2k - 2ln(L) where k is number of ______.
Lower AIC indicates a better model.

o: Bayesian Information Criterion - uses stronger penalty than AIC

q: BIC penalizes complexity more heavily for ______ samples.
BIC tends to select simpler models than AIC.
Rearrange information criteria by complexity penalty:

o: Choosing a subset of relevant features for modeling

q: Backward elimination starts with all features and removes them.
PCA components are orthogonal to each other.

o: Finding latent factors underlying observed variables

q: Factor analysis assumes observed variables are linear combinations of ______.
Factor loadings indicate the correlation between variables and factors.
K-means minimizes within-cluster sum of squares.

o: Partitioning n observations into k clusters

q: K-means is sensitive to initial centroid placement.
Agglomerative clustering starts with ______ observations as clusters.
Cutting a dendrogram at different heights gives different numbers of clusters.

o: A measure of how similar an object is to its cluster vs other clusters

q: Higher silhouette score indicates better clustering.

o: Resampling with replacement to estimate sampling distribution

q: Bootstrap can estimate standard errors and confidence intervals.

o: Leave-one-out resampling to estimate bias and variance

q: Jackknife creates n samples by leaving out ______ observation.
Jackknife can estimate bias in estimators.

o: Testing hypothesis by randomly shuffling data labels

q: Permutation tests make ______ assumptions about distributions.
Permutation tests are exact tests under exchangeability.

o: Joint distribution of multiple random variables

q: The multivariate normal is characterized by mean vector and ______ matrix.
Independence implies zero covariance for multivariate normal.

o: A measure of how two variables change together
A matrix of covariances between all pairs of variables

q: The covariance matrix is symmetric and positive ______.
Diagonal elements of the covariance matrix are variances.

o: Multivariate ANOVA - comparing means on multiple DVs

q: MANOVA tests differences in ______ means simultaneously.
MANOVA controls Type I error when testing multiple dependent variables.

o: Finding linear combinations of features that separate groups

q: LDA finds discriminant functions that maximize ______ separation.
LDA can be used for classification.

o: Correlation between linear combinations of two sets of variables

q: Canonical correlation finds pairs of ______ that maximize correlation.

o: Testing hypothesized causal relationships using correlations

q: Path analysis can decompose correlations into direct and indirect effects.

o: A framework combining path analysis and factor analysis

q: SEM provides fit indices to evaluate model-data correspondence.

o: Analysis of data points collected over time

q: Time series data may exhibit trend, seasonality, and ______ fluctuations.
Stationarity means statistical properties don't change over time.

o: Correlation of a time series with lagged versions of itself

q: The ACF shows autocorrelation at different ______.
White noise has zero autocorrelation at all non-zero lags.
ARIMA(p,d,q) has p AR terms, d differences, and q ______ terms.
ARIMA requires stationary data after differencing.

o: Forecasting method giving more weight to recent observations

q: Simple exponential smoothing uses a ______ parameter alpha.
Holt-Winters method handles trend and seasonality.

o: Data values that are not recorded

q: Multiple imputation creates several plausible values for missing data.

o: Creating multiple plausible datasets and combining results

q: Multiple imputation properly accounts for ______ in imputations.
Rubin's rules combine results from multiple imputations.

o: Statistical combination of results from multiple studies

q: Meta-analysis weights studies by ______ of their estimates.

o: Variation in true effects across studies

q: I^2 measures the ______ of variance due to heterogeneity.

o: Matching treated and control units on probability of treatment

q: Propensity score methods reduce selection bias in observational studies.

o: A variable correlated with treatment but not directly with outcome

q: IV estimation addresses ______ in causal inference.
Valid instruments must satisfy relevance and exclusion restrictions.

o: Comparing changes over time between treatment and control groups
Exploiting a cutoff in treatment assignment

q: RDD uses a ______ that determines treatment.
Sharp RDD has treatment deterministically assigned at cutoff.

o: Calculating the number of observations needed for desired power

q: Sample size formulas depend on effect size, alpha, and power.

o: Adjusting for inflated Type I error when performing many tests

q: Bonferroni correction divides alpha by the number of ______.
FDR (False Discovery Rate) is less conservative than Bonferroni.

o: Expected proportion of false positives among rejected hypotheses

q: FDR control is especially useful in ______ testing.
What is a likelihood ratio test?
LRT statistic = -2 * ln(L0/L1) follows ______ distribution asymptotically.
Likelihood ratio tests compare nested models.
Match the test with its use:

o: Testing a parameter using its estimate and SE

q: Wald, LRT, and Score tests are asymptotically equivalent.

o: Testing based on the score function evaluated at null

q: Score test only requires fitting the ______ model.
Score test is also called Lagrange multiplier test.

o: SE that is valid even if model assumptions are violated

q: Robust SEs are also called sandwich or ______ SEs.
Robust standard errors adjust for heteroskedasticity.

o: Extension of linear model for non-normal distributions

q: GLM links the mean to predictors via a ______ function.
Logistic and Poisson regression are GLMs.
Match the GLM with its link function:
Poisson regression uses log link function.

o: Variance exceeds what the model expects

q: Overdispersion in Poisson can be handled by negative binomial or ______.
Overdispersion leads to underestimated standard errors.

o: Model with both fixed and random effects

q: Random effects account for ______ in clustered data.
Mixed models are also called multilevel or hierarchical models.

o: Mixed model where intercepts vary by group

q: Random intercept allows ______ to differ by group.
Random intercept models account for group-level differences.

o: Proportion of variance attributable to clusters
Method for correlated data using working correlation structure
An unobserved variable inferred from observed data

q: Latent variables are common in ______ analysis and SEM.
Latent variables represent constructs that cannot be directly measured.

o: Modeling relationship between latent trait and item responses

q: IRT models estimate item difficulty and ______.
IRT is used in educational and psychological testing.
Higher reliability means more consistent scores.

o: Whether a test measures what it's supposed to measure

q: Content validity assesses if items cover the ______.
A test can be reliable but not valid.

o: Difference between measured and true value

q: Systematic measurement error leads to bias.

o: Reduction in correlation due to measurement error

q: Measurement error in X attenuates regression ______.
Correction for attenuation can recover true correlations.

o: Inferring individual behavior from group-level data

q: Ecological correlations can differ from ______ correlations.
Ecological fallacy is a type of aggregation bias.

o: Trend reverses when data is aggregated or stratified

q: Simpson's paradox shows importance of considering lurking variables.

o: A third variable that affects both exposure and outcome

q: Confounders must be associated with both exposure and ______.

o: Testing if effect operates through an intermediate variable

q: Indirect effect = a * b where a is X to M and b is M to ______.
Sobel test and bootstrap are used to test mediation.

o: Effect of X on Y depends on a third variable

q: Moderation is tested by including an ______ term.
Moderators change the strength or direction of effects.

o: Assessing how results change under different assumptions

q: Sensitivity analysis is important for unmeasured confounding.

o: Analyzing participants as randomized regardless of compliance

q: ITT analysis is conservative and may underestimate treatment effects.

o: Tendency to publish significant results more than null results

q: Publication bias is detected using ______ plots.
Publication bias leads to overestimation of effects in meta-analysis.

o: Focusing on survivors while ignoring those who did not survive

q: Survivorship bias can make success appear more ______ than it is.
Survivorship bias is common in business and investment analysis.

o: Systematic differences between groups being compared

q: Selection bias occurs when exposure affects ______.
Rearrange study designs by bias control:

o: Systematic errors in measuring exposure or outcome

q: Recall bias is a type of ______ bias.
Match the bias with its source:

o: Generalizability of results to other populations/settings

q: External validity concerns whether results ______ to other contexts.
There is often a trade-off between internal and external validity.

o: Confidence that the treatment caused the observed effect

q: Threats to internal validity include confounding, selection, and ______.

o: Result unlikely to occur by chance if null is true

q: Statistical significance is typically declared when p < ______.
Statistical significance does not imply practical significance.

o: Whether an effect is large enough to matter in practice

q: Practical significance depends on ______ size rather than p-value.
Large samples can make tiny effects statistically significant.
Match the significance type with focus:

o: Many published findings fail to replicate

q: Open data and code sharing support reproducibility.

o: Manipulating analysis to achieve significant p-values

q: What is a prior distribution in Bayesian statistics?
o: Probability distribution representing beliefs before seeing data

q: The prior is updated using data to form the ______.
Bayesian analysis requires specifying a prior.

o: Bayesian interval with specified probability of containing parameter

q: A 95% credible interval has 95% probability of containing the true ______.
Credible intervals have direct probability interpretation.

o: Ratio of marginal likelihoods of two models

q: Bayes factor > 10 is considered ______ evidence for one model.
Bayes factors can be used for model comparison.

o: Multivariate generalization of the beta distribution

q: Dirichlet is conjugate prior for ______ distribution.

o: Estimating prior from the data rather than specifying it

q: Empirical Bayes is sometimes called ______ modeling.
Empirical Bayes can help with shrinkage estimation.

o: Distribution used in reliability and survival analysis

q: Weibull distribution has shape and ______ parameters.

o: Distribution whose logarithm is normally distributed

q: Log-normal is used when data is ______ skewed.
Incomes are often modeled as log-normal.

o: Approximating variance of a function of random variables
Model where data comes from multiple subpopulations

q: Gaussian mixture model combines multiple ______ distributions.
EM algorithm is commonly used to fit mixture models.

o: Expectation-Maximization for finding MLE with latent variables

q: E-step computes expected values of ______ variables.
EM algorithm always converges to at least a local maximum.
